title: Customising the models to compare
text: might wish show different models. now, easiest way save app folder, shown vignette(“getting_started”). open models.R edit models.

title: Customising the models to compare
text: remove models, can add comment (#) front line first defined upper part file models_to_run defined … ignore longer part models_code . remove Trim--fill model, simply need add # shown - alternatively delete line.
code: "Robust Variance Estimation",                      FALSE,       "as.numeric(mod$reg_table$b.r)",      ...  #   "Trim-and-fill",                                   TRUE,        "mod$TE.random",                     ...    "P-uniform star",                                  TRUE,        "mod$est",                            ...

title: Customising the models to compare
text: add edit models, need understand bit structure file. contains two parts - firstly, models_to_run names models details extract summary data, models_code contains code estimate . models_to_run, need provide following details model: name model displayed aggregated TRUE/FALSE value whether needs estimated dataset aggregated sample (.e. without dependent effect sizes) code within “” allows export following model object, called mod: es: effect size LCL & UCL: lower upper bounds 95% confidence intervals effect size k: number effects model estimated models_code, need provide code, ““, estimates model based fields available dataset produced prepare_data() (models aggregated = FALSE) produced df_agg server.R default, includes metaUI__study_id, metaUI__effect_size, metaUI__variance metaUI__se, need fields , need adjust server.R well. model code complicated, might worthwhile create helper functions call within models_code entry. can add models.R need assigned global environment using <<-, e.g., my_meta_fun <<- function(...)

title: Getting started
text: first step, need load import data. metaUI, datafile needs contain: study label identify individual samples (can include multiple effect sizes study label indicate dependent.), effect size measure, variance effect size standard error effect size sample size based p-value effect size data moderators / filters want include Note fields can calculated based others. effect sizes variance, instance, can calculate standard error (taking square root variance), effect sizes, sample sizes p values, can calculate standard error using se..p function included package. first step towards metaUI app, load data. Now create change fields need calculated adjusted. example dataset, taken psymetadata-package, create clear study labels, calculate standard errors p-values, finally relabel potential moderators self-explanatory values. Next, use prepare_data() function format dataset use metaUI package. mostly identifying fields dataset contain specific pieces information. Filters can used subset dataset test moderation. displayed Shiny app, can often good idea rename shown . Note es_type must recognised metafor::escalc() - , deal standardised mean differences, .e. "SMD".
code: app_data <- read.csv(system.file("extdata", "barroso2021.csv", package = "metaUI")) app_data <- app_data %>% mutate(   study_label = paste0(author, " (", pub_year, ")", ": ", study_id),   se = sqrt(vi), p.value = 2 * pnorm(-abs(yi)),   continent = factor(continent) %>%      forcats::fct_recode("North America" = "1", "South America" = "2", "Europe" = "3",                         "Asia" = "4", "Africa" = "5", "Oceania" = "6", "NA" = "-999") %>%      forcats::fct_na_level_to_value("NA"),   teachers = factor(teachers) %>%      forcats::fct_recode(yes = "1", no = "2") ) app_data <- prepare_data(app_data,   study_label = "study_label", es_field = "yi", se = "se", pvalue = "p.value",   sample_size = "ni",   variance = "vi",    filters = c("Publication Year" = "pub_year", "Continent" = "continent", "Teacher Sample" = "teachers"),    es_type = "SMD" )

title: Getting started
text: Now ready launch first version app. useful see whether data read correctly, identify customization want make … just want explore dataset locally. run line , app open web browser.
code: generate_shiny(app_data,                 dataset_name = "Barroso et al 2021 - Maths Anxiety",                 eff_size_type_label = "Fisher's Z scores")

title: Getting started
text: create Shiny app format can customized deployed shinyapps.io, need provide details regarding information displayed path app saved . run , app saved new folder, case my_app_folder. can open app.R folder run Shiny app. customize app, consider editing: models.R adjust meta-analytic models compared main page. See vignette(“customise_models”) instructions . ui.R edit user interface (e.g., labels section) drop certain parts output apart main models (e.g., display z-curve p-curve), server.R modify parts output (instance, use different theme graphs), labels_and_options.R change dynamically displayed text (e.g., welcome message) fundamental options (e.g., aggregating dependent effect sizes).
code: generate_shiny(app_data, dataset_name = "Barroso et al 2021 - Maths Anxiety", eff_size_type_label = "Fisher's Z scores", filter_popups = list("Teacher Sample" = "'Yes' includes both pre-service and practicing teachers."), save_to_folder = "my_app_folder", citation = "Barroso, C., Ganley, C. M., McGraw, A. L., Geer, E. A., Hart, S. A., & Daucourt, M. C. (2021). A meta-analysis of the relation between math anxiety and math achievement. Psychological Bulletin, 147(2), 134.", contact = "l.wallrich@bbk.ac.uk")

title: Getting started
text: want share app wider world, shinyapps.io good platform, free plan sufficient start . used , follow instructions provided Posit/RStudio get started . essence, need create account, install rsconnect package authenticate within package. can run following deploy app: done, app open browser, can copy link address bar. ’s - now meta-analysis Shiny app online.
code: rsconnect::deployApp(appDir = "my_app_folder")

title: Authors and Citation
text: Lukas Wallrich. Author, maintainer, copyright holder. Lukas Röseler. Author, copyright holder. Mathias Harrer. Copyright holder.            Author included p-curve code related helper functions (dmetar package)

title: Authors and Citation
text: Wallrich L, Röseler L (2024). metaUI: Create 'Shiny' Apps Exploration Meta-Analytic Datasets. R package version 0.1.2,  https://github.com/LukasWallrich/metaUI, https://lukaswallrich.github.io/metaUI/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {metaUI: Create 'Shiny' Apps for the Exploration of Meta-Analytic Datasets},   author = {Lukas Wallrich and Lukas Röseler},   year = {2024},   note = {R package version 0.1.2,  https://github.com/LukasWallrich/metaUI},   url = {https://lukaswallrich.github.io/metaUI/}, }

what: Create Shiny Apps for the Exploration of Meta-Analytic Datasets
title: Create Shiny Apps for the Exploration of Meta-Analytic Datasets
text: metaUI package allows users quickly create powerful customisable Shiny web apps allow readers explore meta-analytic dataset depth. can explore impact different analytical choices, see results subgroups particular interest, even modify update underlying dataset. motivation package came fact meta-analyses based rich datasets can analyzed numerous ways, unlikely authors readers always agree “best ways” analyze data. Whether comes choice model (e.g., random versus fixed effects), methods assessing adjusting publication bias (e.g., z-curve, p-curve, PET/PEESE etc), moderators considered, disagreements likely arise. can lead inclusion lengthy robustness checks alternative analyses time-consuming difficult digest. metaUI, R package supports researchers creating interactive Shiny web apps can help - apps allow readers (reviewers) explore meta-analytic datasets variety different ways. Apart allowing readers (reviewers) assess robustness trustworthiness results comprehensively, metaUI apps allow users assess results relevant , filtering dataset focus specific group participants, region, outcome variable, research method. opportunity users download dataset used upload alternatives, also facilitate updating meta-analyses. idea came researchers created similar web apps meta-analyses well received, yet require substantial time investment advanced coding skills create. metaUI, researchers can get working app swiftly – still flexibility tailor display line interests requirements. package now stable beta-stage, yet feedback contributions welcome!

title: Create Shiny Apps for the Exploration of Meta-Analytic Datasets
text: can install development version metaUI GitHub :
code: if (!require(remotes)) install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("LukasWallrich/metaUI")

title: Create Shiny Apps for the Exploration of Meta-Analytic Datasets
text: best way get started RStudio metaUI template - RStudio, go File -> New File -> R Markdown select Template Create metaUI Shiny app. see template readable format, select Visual just file opened enter Visual Editor. can follow step--step instructions. Outside R Studio, can run file.edit(system.file("rmarkdown/templates/create--metaui-shiny-app/skeleton/skeleton.Rmd", package = "metaUI")) open template file take . Getting started vignette provides step--step example … may want watch video tutorial step--step walk-.

title: Create Shiny Apps for the Exploration of Meta-Analytic Datasets
text: Much package code based two previous interactive meta-analyses apps: Röseler, L., Körner, R., & Schütz, . (2021). Dynamic Meta-Analysis. Retrieved https://osf.io/ns65r/, Shiny app accessible Röseler, L., Weber, L., Helgerth, K. . C., Stich, E., Günther, M., Tegethoff, P., Wagner, F. S., Ambrus, E., Antunovic, M., Barrera, F., Halali, E., Ioannidis, K., McKay, R., Milstein, N., Molden, D. C., Papenmeier, F., Rinn, R., Schreiter, M. L., Zimdahl, M., Allen, E., Bahník, S., Baumeister, R. F., Bermeitinger, C., Bickenbach, S. L. C., Blank, P. ., Blower, F. B. N., Bögler, H. L., Boo, F. L., Boruchowicz, C., Bühler, R. L., Burgmer, P., Cheek, N., N., Dohle, S., Dorsch, L., Dück, M. S., Fels, S.-., Fischer, . L., Frech, M.-L., Freira, L., Friedinger, K., Genschow, O., Harris, ., Hartig, B., Häusser, J. ., Hedgebeth, M., Henkel, M., Horvath, D., Hügel, J. C., Igna, E. L. E., Imhoff, R., Intelmann, P., Karg, . H., Klamar, ., Klein, C., Klusmann, B., Knappe, E., Köppel, L.-M., Koßmann, L., Kraft, P., Kroworsch, M. K., Krueger, S. M., Kühling, S., Lagator, S., Lammers, J., Loschelder, D. D., Navajas, J., Norem, J., K., Novak, J. Onuki, Y., Page, E., Panse, F., Pavlovic, Z., Pearton, J., Rebholz, T. R., Rodgers, S., Röseler, J. J., Rostekova, ., Roßmaier, K. V., Sartorio, M., Scheelje, L., Schindler, S., Schreiner, N. B., Seida, C., Shanks, D. R., Siems, M.-C., Stitz, M., Starkulla, M., Stäglich, M., Thies, K., Thum, E., Undorf, M., Unger, B. D., Urlichich, D., Vadillo, M. ., Wackershauser-Sablotny, V., Wessel, ., Wolf, H., Zhou, ., & Schütz, . (2022). OpAQ: Open Anchoring Quest, Version 1.1.48.95. https://dx.doi.org/10.17605/OSF.IO/YGNVB, Shiny app accessible sample data taken psymetadata-package, initially extracted following article: Barroso C, Ganley CM, McGraw AL, Geer EA, Hart SA, Daucourt MC (2021). “meta-analysis relation math anxiety math achievement.” Psychological Bulletin, 147(2), 134. Data details also available https://osf.io/5admx/.

what: Create the about text for the app — create_about
title: Create the about text for the app — create_about
text: function generally called internally generate_shiny().

title: Create the about text for the app — create_about
code: create_about(   dataset_name,   date = format(Sys.Date(), "%d %b %Y"),   citation = "",   osf_link = "",   contact = "",   list_packages = TRUE )

title: Create the about text for the app — create_about
text: dataset_name Name dataset date Date last update. Defaults current date. citation Citation requested author. Defaults empty string. osf_link Link OSF (similar) project data materials available. Defaults empty string. contact Contact information, typically email. Defaults empty string. list_packages packages used app listed page? TRUE, list packages used default configuration. display different packages (e.g., added/removed models), pass character vector packages display.

title: Create the about text for the app — create_about
text: HTML code panel Shiny app

title: Generate Shiny app — generate_shiny
text: function generates Shiny app. main function package. app can either launched directly, saved folder. saved, folder contain code data needed run app. app can launched app.R file folder, modified editing server.R, ui.R, global.R models.R .

title: Generate Shiny app — generate_shiny
code: generate_shiny(   dataset,   dataset_name,   eff_size_type_label = NA,   models = get_model_tibble,   filter_popups = list(),   save_to_folder = NA,   launch_app = is.na(save_to_folder),   ...,   options = list() )

title: Generate Shiny app — generate_shiny
text:
dataset Dataframe returned prepare_data() dataset_name Name dataset eff_size_type_label label used describe effect size. NA, effect type code dataset used. models models included app. Can either function call, tibble, path file. want change default models, look vignette /get_model_tibble() documentation. Passing file (e.g. "my_models.R") particularly helpful include helper functions save app. , must assign tibble variable called models_to_run (.e. using <-). filter_popups Named list content popup windows provide details filter variables. can contain HTML formatting, wrapped HTML(), instance: list(Year = HTML("<>Note:
refers data collection reported, otherwise publication year.) save_to_folder specified, code data app saved folder. Defaults NA, means nothing saved. folder exists, user asked confirm overwriting - unless script run non-interactive mode, case folder overwritten without asking. launch_app app launched? Defaults TRUE saved (.e. save_to_folder NA), FALSE otherwise. ... Arguments passed create_about date Date last update. Defaults current date. citation Citation requested author. Defaults empty string. osf_link Link OSF (similar) project data materials available. Defaults empty string. contact Contact information, typically email. Defaults empty string. list_packages packages used app listed page? TRUE, list packages used default configuration. display different packages (e.g., added/removed models), pass character vector packages display. options List detailed options customise app. sensible defaults thus rarely needed. max_forest_plot_rows Numeric. maximum number effects forest plot displayed? Defaults 100. effect sizes selected, message shown instead. shiny_theme Character. One shinythemes style app. Defaults "yeti", see ?shinythemes::shinythemes options. selection_list_threshold Numeric. many filter levels selection box shown instead check boxes? Defaults 11.

title: Generate Shiny app — generate_shiny
text: function meaningful return value - rather launches Shiny app /saves disk.

title: Generate Shiny app — generate_shiny
code: # First, use prepare_data() to create your dataset. if (exists("app_data")) {   generate_shiny(app_data,     dataset_name = "Barroso et al 2021 - Maths Anxiety",     eff_size_type_label = "Fisher's Z scores") }

title: Get model specifications — get_model_tibble
text: function contains model specifications compared Shiny app. want maintain default, just call generate_shiny() without specifying models argument. want change default models, look vignette /source code function (running get_model_tibble console) modify accordingly.

title: Get model specifications — get_model_tibble
code: get_model_tibble()

title: Get model specifications — get_model_tibble
text: tibble models included app - including details estimate extract relevant information model output.

title: Get model specifications — get_model_tibble
code: # Run the function to get the models mod <- get_model_tibble() # Modify them as desired mod$name[1] <- "RE 2-level model" # Then use when generating the app if (exists("app_data")) {   generate_shiny(app_data,     dataset_name = "Barroso et al 2021 - Maths Anxiety",     eff_size_type_label = "Fisher's Z scores") }

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: function performs \(p\)-curve analysis using meta object calculated effect size data. See dmetar documentation examples.

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
code: pcurve(x, effect.estimation = FALSE, N, dmin = 0, dmax = 1)

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: x Either object class meta, generated metagen, metacont, metacor, metainc, metabin function, dataframe containing calculated effect size (named TE, log-transformed based ratio), standard error (named seTE) study label (named studlab) study. effect.estimation Logical. true effect size underlying p-curve estimated? set TRUE, vector containing total sample size study must provided N. FALSE default. N numeric vector length number effect sizes included x specifying total sample size \(N\) corresponding effect. needed effect.estimation = TRUE. dmin effect.estimation = TRUE: lower limit effect size (\(d\)) space true effect size searched. Must greater equal 0. Default 0. dmax effect.estimation = TRUE: upper limit effect size (\(d\)) space true effect size searched. Must greater 0. Default 1.

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: Returns plot main results pcurve analysis: P-curve plot: plot displaying observed \(p\)-curve significance results right-skewness flatness test. Number studies: number studies provided analysis, number significant \(p\)-values included analysis, number studies \(p<0.025\) used half-curve tests. Test results: results right-skewness flatness test, including \(p_{binomial}\) value, well \(z\) \(p\) value full half-curve test. Power Estimate: power estimate 95% confidence interval. Evidential value: Two lines displaying evidential value present /absent/inadequate based results (using guidelines Simonsohn et al., 2015, see Details). True effect estimate: effect.estimation set TRUE, estimated true effect \(\hat{d}\) returned additionally. results saved variable, list class pcurve containing following objects returned: pcurveResults: data frame containing results right-skewness flatness test, including \(p_{binomial}\) value, well \(z\) \(p\) value full half-curve test. Power: power estimate 95% confidence interval. PlotData: data frame data used \(p\)-curve plot. Input: data frame containing provided effect sizes, calculated \(p\)-values individual results included (significant) effect. EvidencePresent, EvidenceAbsent, kInput, kAnalyzed, kp0.25: results \(p\)-curve analysis, including presence/absence evidence interpretation, number provided/significant/\(p<0.025\) studies. I2: \(^2\)-Heterogeneity studies provided input (x class meta). class.meta.object: class original object provided x.

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: P-curve Analysis \(P\)-curve analysis (Simonsohn, Simmons & Nelson, 2014, 2015) proposed method detect \(p\)-hacking publication bias meta-analyses. \(P\)-Curve assumes publication bias generated researchers publish non-significant results, also analysts “play” around data ("\(p\)-hacking"; e.g., selectively removing outliers, choosing different outcomes, controlling different variables) non-significant finding becomes significant (.e., \(p<0.05\)). method assumes specific research question, \(p\)-values smaller 0.05 included studies follow right-skewed distribution true effect exists, even power single studies (relatively) low. Conversely, left-skewed \(p\)-value distribution indicates presence \(p\)-hacking absence true underlying effect. control "ambitious" \(p\)-hacking, \(P\)-curve also incorporates "half-curve" test (Simonsohn, Simmons & Nelson, 2014, 2015). Simonsohn et al. (2014) stress \(p\)-curve analysis used test statistics actually interest context included study, detailed table documenting reported results used \(p\)-curve analysis created communicating results (link). Implementation function generate \(p\)-curve conduct analysis, function reuses parts R code underlying P-curve App 4.052 (Simonsohn, 2017). effect sizes included meta object data.frame provided x transformed \(z\)-values internally, used calculate p-values conduct Stouffer Binomial test used \(p\)-curve analysis. Interpretations function concerning presence absence/inadequateness evidential value made according guidelines described Simonsohn, Simmons Nelson (2015): Evidential value present: right-skewness test significant half curve \(p<0.05\) \(p\)-value right-skewness test \(<0.1\) half full curve. Evidential value absent inadequate: flatness test \(p<0.05\) full curve flatness test half curve binomial test \(p<0.1\). effect size estimation, pcurve function implements parts loss function presented Simonsohn, Simmons Nelson (2014b). function generates loss function candidate effect sizes \(\hat{d}\), using \(D\)-values Kolmogorov-Smirnov test metric fit, value \(\hat{d}\) minimizes \(D\) estimated true effect. note lack robustness \(p\)-curve analysis results noted meta-analyses substantial heterogeneity (van Aert, Wicherts, & van Assen, 2016). Following van Aert et al., adjusted effect size estimates reported interpreted analyses \(^2\) values 50 percent. warning message therefore printed pcurve function x class meta -study heterogeneity meta-analysis substantial (.e., \(^2\) greater 50 percent).

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: Harrer, M., Cuijpers, P., Furukawa, T., & Ebert, D. D. (2019). Meta-Analysis R: Hands-Guide. DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.2551803. Chapter 9.2. Simonsohn, U., Nelson, L. D., & Simmons, J. P. (2014a). P-curve: Key File-drawer. Journal Experimental Psychology, 143(2), 534. Simonsohn, U., Nelson, L. D. & Simmons, J. P. (2014b). P-Curve Effect Size: Correcting Publication Bias Using Significant Results. Perspectives Psychological Science 9(6), 666–81. Simonsohn, U., Nelson, L. D. & Simmons, J. P. (2015). Better P-Curves: Making P-Curve Analysis Robust Errors, Fraud, Ambitious P-Hacking, Reply Ulrich Miller (2015). Journal Experimental Psychology, 144(6), 1146-1152. Simonsohn, U. (2017). R code P-Curve App 4.052. http://p-curve.com/app4/pcurve_app4.052.r (Accessed 2019-08-16). Van Aert, R. C., Wicherts, J. M., & van Assen, M. . (2016). Conducting meta-analyses based p values: Reservations recommendations applying p-uniform p-curve. Perspectives Psychological Science, 11(5), 713-729.

title: Perform a p-curve analysis — pcurve
text: Mathias Harrer & David Daniel Ebert

what: Import data from a file and return a data frame — prepare_data
title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — prepare_data
text: may want use metafor::escalc() function metafor package calculate effect sizes variances preparation function.

title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — prepare_data
code: prepare_data(   data,   study_label,   es_field,   se,   pvalue,   sample_size,   variance,   filters,   url = NA,   es_type = "SMD",   article_label = NA,   es_label = NA,   na.rm = "es_related",   arrange_filters = c("given", "alphabetical", "leave"),   keep_missing_level = FALSE )

title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — prepare_data
text: data path .csv file read data frame study_label Character. Name field use id/study label es_field Character. Name field use effect size se Character. Name field use standard error effect size. pvalue Character. Name field use p-value effect size. sample_size Character. Name field use sample size variance Character. Name field use sampling variances. filters Character. List fields use filters - can named different labels displayed url Character. Field URLs DOIs link . DOIs can format "10.1234/5678" full links. Defaults NA. es_type Character. Type effect size. Defaults "SMD" (standardized mean difference). Check metafor::escalc() function options. article_label Character. Field article labels. used report number references addition number independent samples. es_label Character. Label individual effect sizes - needed multiple effect sizes per study/sample. Defaults NA. Defaults NA, case, multiple effect sizes simply numbered. na.rm rows missing values removed? Can TRUE, FALSE "es_related" - last default drops rows missing values variables used standard meta-analysis models, namely es_field, sample_size, variance, se pvalue. Setting TRUE also drops rows missing values filters etc, might often unnecessary. Conversely, setting FALSE might lead issues model - unless post-process data change models analyses included app. arrange_filters Character. filters arranged app? Options "given" filters argument, "alphabetical" "leave" (dataset). Defaults "given". keep_missing_level Logical. (Missing)-level kept even filters missing values? Might advisable expect users upload new data missing values. Defaults FALSE.

title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — prepare_data
text: tibble data file/input reformatted metaUI

title: Import data from a file and return a data frame — prepare_data
code: if (FALSE) { import_data("my_meta.csv", "study_id", "cohens_d", c("Country" = "country", "Year" = "year")) }

what: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
text: function calculates standard error effect size provided exact \(p\)-value (continuous) effect size according formula Altman Bland (2011). See dmetar documentation examples.

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
code: se.from.p(effect.size, p, N, effect.size.type = 'difference',     calculate.g = FALSE)

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
text: effect.size Numeric vector single number. effect size, standardized mean difference, Hedges' \(g\) continuous effect size. p Numeric vector single number. exact \(p\)-value corresponding effect size. N Numeric vector single number. total number samples used calculate effect size/\(p\)-value. effect.size.type type effect sizes provided effect.size. effect sizes based differences (e.g., mean differences), parameter set "difference". effect sizes based ratios (e.g., risk ratio, odds ratio), parameter set "ratio". calculate.g Logical. Calculates standardized mean difference corrected small sample bias (Hedges' \(g\)). FALSE default.

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
text: dataframe containing following columns: (log)EffectSize: input effect size. Log-transformed effect.size.type "ratio". Hedges.g: calculated Hedges' g values (calculate.g=TRUE). (log)StandardError: standard error (SE) effect size. Log-transformed effect.size.type "ratio". (log)LLCI (log)ULCI: lower upper 95% confidence interval effect size. Log-transformed effect.size.type="ratio".

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
text: function calculates standard error, standard deviation 95% confidence interval effect size given effect size exact \(p\)-value. function can used : effect sizes based differences (e.g., mean differences) setting effect.size.type "difference", effect sizes based ratios (e.g. risk ratios, odds ratios hazard ratios) setting effect.size.type "ratio". ratios used, function returns log-transformed effect sizes, standard error, standard deviation confidence interval, can used meta-analytic pooling using metagen function, along original effect size confidence interval.

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
text: Altman D.G. & Bland J.M. (2011) obtain confidence interval p value. BMJ 343:d2090.

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p
text: Mathias Harrer & David Daniel Ebert

title: Calculate the standard error from the effect size and p-value — se.from.p

metaUI 0.1.2 (under development)
text: generate_shiny() gained options argument allow customization app. Currently allows setting Shiny theme, limit number rows forest plot, threshold switching checkboxes selection lists based number moderator levels, sensible defaults. prepare_data gained argument arrange_filters allow ordering filters app. now defaults ordering order passed function, can changed alphabetical ordering (case order columns determines position) Added ability create app without filters/moderators Now shows “(Missing)” level missing values filter/moderator - unless

title: metaUI 0.1.2 (under development)
text: Corrected random intercept specification rma.mv (added sparse = TRUE speed model fitting) Fixed bug describing moderators “”-category already existed Fixed creation code install required packages added check ensure filters factors numeric (#28) Waffle plots sample description longer run colors presence 11 categories.

title: metaUI 0.1.1
text: Fixed issue k displayed moderators spaces names Simplified implementation generate_shiny() - now always saved, either provided path temporary files, launched file. increase robustness. Also, removed unnecessary app.R globals.R need called explicitly. Added NEWS.md file track changes package. Added explicit option include exclude NAs filters report NA share Sample descriptives Added Reset button reset filters Added option add popups filter, specifying filter_popups generate_shiny()
